name: Erdős–Turán conjecture on additive bases
summary: The Erdős–Turán conjecture states that if a set of integers \(A\) is an additive basis of order 2 (meaning every natural number can be written as the sum of at most two elements from \(A\)), then the number of ways each integer can be represented as a sum of two elements from \(A\) must be unbounded. In other words, there must be integers that can be written as a sum of two elements from \(A\) in arbitrarily many ways.
head: A set \(A\) of non-negative integers is an asymptotic additive base of order 2 (meaning every sufficiently large integer \(N\) can be represented as a sum \(a+b\) with \(a,b\in A\) at least once).
tail: The number of representations of \(N\) as \(a+b\) with \(a,b\in A\) (often denoted as \(R_{A}(N)\)) is unbounded as \(N\rightarrow \infty \) (i.e., \(\limsup _{N\rightarrow \infty }R_{A}(N)=\infty \)).
